question.body: Which molecule seems to pass freely through the membrane?

response.feedback: Incorrect. Look again at the cholesterol molecules. See how they tend to gather within the hydrophobic part of the phospholipid bilayer? This is because they are hydrophobic.
Incorrect. The sodium ion cannot pass through the membrane at all! This is because it is relatively big and charged.
Correct. Water passes freely through the membrane, even though it is polar. This is because it is quite small.

part.hint: Reset the animation and focus on each molecule, one at a time. Describe their movements.
The cholesterol seems to pass through the membrane sometimes, but often stays in the hydrophobic part of the membrane.
The ion does not pass through the membrane at all.

body.p: Which molecule does not pass through the membrane at all?

response.feedback: Incorrect. While cholesterol doesnot pass freely through the membrane, it does pass through. This is because it is hydrophobic.
Correct. The sodium ion cannot pass through the membrane at all! This is because it is relatively big and charged.
Incorrect. Water passes freely through the membrane. This is because it is small, even though it is polar.

part.hint: Reset the animation and focus on each molecule, one at a time. Describe their movements.
The water passes through the membrane freely.
The cholesterol seems to pass through the membrane sometimes, but often stays in the hydrophobic part of the membrane.

body.p: Which of the following molecules would cross the membrane most easily?

response.feedback: Correct. Methane is small and non-polar.
Incorrect. Chloride is small, but ions don't easily cross the membrane.
Incorrect. Glucose is large and polar.

Methane is a small molecule. Glucose is very large. Chloride ions are relatively small.
Chloride ions are charged ions. Glucose is also polar (see the OH atoms). Methane is non-polar.
